qas.question: Why is being a charity beneficial to Eton?
What service does Eton provide to the local community free of charge?
What was the full price of Eton per student in 2010-2011?
How much did estimated tax breaks save per student in 1992?
What is the largest charity in the UK?
In what year did David Jewell become the Master of Haileybury?
In what year did Tony Little retire as Head Master?
How much did it cost to attend Eton in 2006?
How much was the fee to attend Eton in 2010?

context: Until 18 December <b6_0>2010<b6_0/>, <b4_0>Eton College<b4_0/> was an exempt charity under English law (Charities Act 1993, Schedule 2). Under the provisions of the Charities Act 2006, it is now an excepted charity, and fully registered with the Charities Commission, and is now one of the 100 largest charities in the UK. As a charity, it benefits from <a0_0>substantial tax breaks<a0_0/>. It was calculated by the late David Jewell, former Master of Haileybury, that in 1<b5_0>992<b5_0/> such tax breaks saved the School about <a3_0>£1,945 per pupil per year<a3_0/>, although he had no direct connection with the School. This subsidy has declined since the 2001 abolition by the Labour Government of state-funded scholarships (formerly known as "assisted places") to independent schools. However, no child attended Eton on this scheme, meaning that the actual level of state assistance to the School has always been lower. Eton's retiring Head Master, Tony Little, has claimed that the benefits that Eton provides to the local community free of charge (<a1_0>use of its facilities<a1_0/>, etc.) have a higher value than the tax breaks it receives as a result of its charitable status. The fee for the academic year 2010–2011 was <a2_0><b7_0>£29,862<b7_0/> (approximately <b8_0>US$48,600<b8_0/> or €35,100<a2_0/> as of March 2011), although the sum is considerably lower for those pupils on bursaries and scholarships.
